text:
As things start to
open up, I feel —

“As states reopen,
crowded scenes —”

“Every bar in New York City
is going to feel like St.

Patrick’s Day fell
on Cinco de Mayo.
You know what I’m saying?”

“And you’re going
to shake hands.

And you’re going to
give each other a hug.”
[SIRENS]
[SIGHING DEEPLY]
[EXHALING SHAKILY]
[EXHALING SHARPLY]

In my body, I feel
a sense of fogginess,

a heavy fog slowly floating
in the background and weighing
me down.

Going back out onto busy
streets again honestly makes
me feel a little nauseous.

My muscles tense up and I
feel my heart racing faster.
It’s basically tension.

Those tense points
in my shoulder,

those queasy parts of my
stomach, my lower back,
my brow.

After the shutdown
started, it really felt like
the volume got turned down.

And it was like
we went to sleep,

humanity kind of
went to sleep.

In that time period, I
think I just really felt,

as an introvert, kind of how I
imagine a circus animal would

feel on a day when
there’s no shows.

It was like a snow
day from life.
I felt safer.
I felt safer.

When I’m at home
and I’m on Zoom,
you only see me from here up.

And so often, you can’t even
see that I’m a wheelchair
user.

Once the pandemic began and
so much of what we did shifted

to being virtual,
for a whole year,

I didn’t have to worry
about getting on a train

or a plane, or grappling
with any sort of inaccessible
travel.

And there was a certain
lightness to feeling like I

could say yes to more things,
and not having to worry about

the toll that it would
take on my body.

When it first
started, the pandemic,

it was very
comfortable for me.
I began to feel very relaxed.

I kind of wondered,
you know, why
I was feeling so comfortable.

My husband is
white, and we often

have conversations with folks
that we meet on the street,
and I become invisible.

I go into a market, and
I’m either ignored totally
or followed and watched.
That’s a microaggression.

And it culminates, and
builds and builds and builds.
It takes away your energy.
It makes you sick.

After we began to come
out of the pandemic,

it was during those moments of
engagement with white people,

to be frank, that I began to
feel those things in my body

that had gone away
during the pandemic.

The respite has transformed
me because I’ve had rest.

I’m honestly incredibly
nervous to return to any kind
of normalcy.

Oh my gosh, the world is not
designed for disabled people.

I’m right back to having to
plan for all of the potential

accessibility pitfalls,
whether it is a broken

elevator or a building
with stairs but no ramp

or a doorway that’s too
narrow to get through.
So I have re-entry anxiety.

The pressure to perform
and project and engage
in the world is intensified.

And that is
overwhelming to me.

I pulled into the shopping
center near my house,

and the parking lot
was full of cars.

And I just felt this,
like, clutch in my heart.

As the world picks up pace, I
am ready to further disengage
from it.

Black people, white
people, all people,

we all have a responsibility
to transform ourselves.

Why were we able to make the
world virtually accessible

only when it mattered
for non-disabled people?

Why can’t we do
that all the time?

I’m nervous that we will
return to the before,

not having learned any
lessons from this time.

I wish the pandemic had never
happened, but because it did,

I hope that it hasn’t
happened in vain.

I want the end of the
pandemic for all of us,

but I don’t want to go
back to the way it was.

I don’t want to see
us return to normal.

I want to see us
return to better.

The normal was not
working out for all of us.
No.
